body:
The giant and politically influential Service Employees International Unionâs endorsement of Hillary ClintonÂ TuesdayÂ gives the Democratic front-runner her 13thÂ nod from a national labor union, underscoring the growing strength of her campaign.
Mrs. Clintonâs chief Democratic rival Bernie Sanders has received just two endorsements from national labor unions,Â reflecting the challenge ahead for the Vermont senator whoâs also trailing Mrs. Clinton in polls.
With SEIUâs backing, Mrs. Clinton has secured support from many of the nationâs largest labor unions, including the National Education Association and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. The unions that have endorsed Mrs. Clinton collectively represent well over half of the nationâs 14.6 million union members in 2014.
SEIU, which has nearly two million members, said it chose to support Mrs. Clinton because sheâs a leader whoâll fight to raise wages and stand up for working people. The union also said she values the kind of care work that many SEIU members do daily, including the work of home-care aides whoâve been fighting for higher minimum pay.
âSEIU members and working families across America are part of a growing movement to build a better future for their families, and Hillary Clinton will support and stand with them,â the unionâs President Mary Kay Henry said in a statementÂ Tuesday.
SEIU said it spent monthsÂ gauging its membersâ support of the candidates, including through polls and tele-town hall meetings. Mrs. Clinton consistently received more than 72% of membersâ support, an SEIU spokesman said.
That wasnât enough to stop a backlash on social mediaÂ TuesdayÂ from disgruntled SEIU members who back Mr. Sanders. Members of a group called SEIU for Bernie had been voicing concern for weeks that an endorsement of Mrs. Clinton could undermine the Fight for $15 campaign. The SEIU-funded wage campaign began with New York fast-food workers and has evolved into a nationwide push for a $15 federal minimum wage. The campaign is also trying to use the wage issue to build a bloc of like-minded voters for the 2016 elections.Â
Mr. Sanders backs a $15 federal minimum wage while Mrs. Clinton has said she supports a federal minimum of $12. When asked last week whether that would affect SEIUâs endorsement process, the unionâs president Ms. Henry suggested thereâs room for improvement. âFor us, itâs about driving the movement alongside of the candidates,â she said in an interview.
For its part, the Sanders campaign sought to downplay the union endorsements for Mrs. Clinton, focusing instead on the support it has received from rank-and-file union members.
“We are gratified that hundreds of thousands of workers are part of the growing grassroots movement supporting Bernie’s campaign to help working families by raising the minimum wage, providing health care for all and making college affordable,” said Michael Briggs, a spokesman for Mr. Sandersâs campaign.

description: The giant and politically influential Service Employees International Union’s endorsement of Hillary Clinton Tuesday gives the Democratic front-runner her 13th nod from a national labor union, underscoring the growing strength of her campaign.
title: SEIU’s Clinton Nod Signals Campaign’s Momentum Growing
orgs: American Federation of State , County and Municipal Employees
